body:
Yes I think this a problem.  It is working as designed but it isn't what users expect!

This was introduced in #1837 by  d758e1908ee679948f0503cb6b961a4d67bc8491 to copy empty directories.

However if you filter all the files out then rclone thinks you have lots of empty directories and creates them all.

Perhaps a compromise would be to skip making the empty directories completely if any filtering is active?

What do you think? @JRWR and also @ishuah since you wrote that original code?
That would be good, OR a flag to toggle not to copy empties would be a good feature

I think your problem might be different to the one above...

You have lots of empty directories in the source already...

What you could do is add `--delete-empty-src-dirs` to the `rclone move` command - this will remove the empty source directories.  (Or run `rclone rmdirs` before the move).

Maybe you are right a flag not to create empty directories for `rclone sync/copy/move` would be the right thing.
Well the interesting thing is, the dirs Exist already on the source, but it just keeps remaking them. but ya, a flag to ignore empty dirs syncing to the remote

> Maybe you are right a flag not to create empty directories for `rclone sync/copy/move` would be the right thing.

If this applies even when using filters, it would help a lot! :)

I think the right thing would be a flag *to* create empty directories (e.g. `--create-empty-src-dirs`). While I can see the use for it, I can't imagine why that should be the default behaviour. I know aldones says the opposite in the old issue, but... no? Maybe I just used rclone for too long with the old behaviour but it seems bizarre to me.

I've been meaning to make an issue about this myself, as I have a folder on the cloud with upwards of 800 folders (one per day for several years) and used to use include filters to pull down just a few files. Since d758e1908ee679948f0503cb6b961a4d67bc8491 it now recreates the entire folder structure (800+ folders and 5-6x as many subfolders) every time. It's... mildly annoying.

Simply disabling the creation of empty directories whenusing  filters only creates a different problem: perhaps a user doesn't want to download any files but does want to duplicate a folder structure so it's easier to put files in the right place before uploading. Currently he can do so by excluding all files.

This behavior has had a lot of conflicting views ever since I implemented it. #2629 is a request to have this feature on the `copyto` command. Expected default behavior (in regard to creating empty dirs) varies from user to user. 

After some consideration, I'm leaning towards @wlerin's suggestion. It's much more consistent behavior.

What do you think @ncw?

I think a default behavior of *not* creating empty directories makes more sense. The current behavior which creates the whole directory tree (many empty directories) when filters are being used, even when those directories do not contain any of the filtered files, seems quite counterintuitive (more details [here](https://forum.rclone.org/t/rclone-sync-do-not-create-excluded-and-empty-folders-on-google-drive/8207)). However, as long as the user can control this (a flag to force creation of empty folders, or a flag to suppress creation of empty folders), either is workable.

Recreating empty directories on `rclone copy` seems to invalidate the advice in the `copy` documentation:

> See the --no-traverse option for controlling whether rclone lists the destination directory or not. Supplying this option when copying a small number of files into a large destination can speed transfers up greatly.

> For example, if you have many files in /path/to/src but only a few of them change every day, you can to copy all the files which have changed recently very efficiently like this:

> rclone copy --max-age 24h --no-traverse /path/to/src remote:

I'm watching `rclone copy --max-age ... --no-traverse` take a long time to recreate directories unnecessarily.

issue.title: Rclone creates (or logs that is creating) empty directories on every sync

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

Rclone creates (or logs that is creating) empty directories on every sync

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

Current git

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

Linux, 64

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

Local file system for testing

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```
cd /tmp
mkdir t1
mkdir t1/empty
rclone -vv copy t1 t2
rclone -vv copy t1 t2
```


#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

Both the copy commands produce this log

```
2019/02/15 11:02:38 DEBUG : empty: Making directory
```

Rclone should know while it is traversing the tree about the empty directories in the source so it shouldn't have to make them.
